content: I'd like to add cover art to this puzzle if there are no objections.
Tests 5 and 6 are not corresponding to validators 5 and 6. Morevover, no test covers the diagonal distance case !!!!

This puzzle being easier than a Clash of code, I have changed its difficulty from medium to easy.
I have also improved the tags.


That being said, I am really upset with this approval. :@

A few concerns:
 - That's definitely easy, not medium.
 - Why do you define some light levels for the spots while you are only interested in counting 0-level spots? It feels like you should just talk about dark & lit/enlighted spots and say something such as "a spot is lit if and only if it is at a uniform-distance <=L-1 of a candle".
 - The following sentence is unclear: "If a spot is touched by two candles, it will have the larger "light" it can have." Do you mean that the spot gets the max of its light levels from the different candles?? But anyway, what's the point as we do not care about light level (cf previous point)?
 - The tags are bad: "Map" also refers to an associative data structure, and "Light"...

Easy version of https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/179308ea4495a7fe36cec1429ea11d433bde , which is a CoC (a hard one, but still feasible).

Moreover, I really dislike the extra spaces between the elements of the grid.

I like it, but you could add some limit test cases such as N = 24 or L =0...
And maybe do even larger rooms to challenge us a bit :-)

Liked it; solved it.

My only suggestion would be to create less "friendly" tests/validators.  I'd like to see more edge cases and attempts to "break" people's solutions.  Some examples:

- A room that's MASSIVE (like 5000x5000) to force people to think outside the box (like Hoeskioeh's solution).
- A room with zero candles.
- A room with candles in every square.
- A 1x1 room.
- Any combination of the above.

...But that may just be personal preference.

Regardless, upvoted.

nice.  solved.
sure it's medium?  

the lumen value itself isn't really needed, as all you have to to is describe a square centered around each candle with base length (2*L+1), so the actual value within these exclusion squares is irrelevant if you are only asking for dark spots with L==0  
i.e. the rule "spot is touched by two candles" is never needed...  

PS: and if you want, you could leave out the whole grid input and just give the candle coordinates, since the grid size is known...

I think it's easy, but all my other ones were easy as well and they ranked it to medium, so I just skipped that step.

I added those rules, because I plan to have additional versions, where the rules will be important.
Additional rules I think are never meaningless, it makes the others wonder, why...

I was thinking about having only the coordinates, but then I have to have a number of candles, and then coordinates, which is more...
I added some more test cases
I added some more test cases
How do you find those?!? Is there a list or something? Or did you bookmark them all?
And once again this gets accepted without waiting for the concerns to be addressed or at least answered to...

Sorry for that.
I too think it is easy, however I think my previous two were easy as well (tagged to that), and they changed both to medium.

I added this because I plan to have a second version with a bit more difficulty, but same rules, where it counts.

It is actually important. If one spot is touched by two candlelight, it can have the additional value of the candlelights. If that would be the case, it can create a larger light source, and cause a whole different  result.

I don't know how many times I've read "my puzzle isn't great but that's because it's meant to be the first in a series" in the last few months, but why not just sorting out your ideas and make ONE actually good puzzle?

As for your "additional value" point, I don't get it: Do you mean that a spot lit at level L implicitly acts as a candle of level L?

It can work like that too. Some might think, that if it is like the foloowing scheme, with level 3 lights, than the middle point is level 4, and act as a level 4 starting point. Which makes the entire field lit. I wanted to make sure, that this is not happening.

XXXXXXX

XXCXCXX
XXXXXXX

Ok, but you don't actually say that a lit spot acts as a candle in the statement, so why would anyone assume it works like that?

Very good question. I would ask this from the creator, because I donâ€™t also say that it does not act as a candle.
If we count the wave structure of the light, and if we assume the light in this case is similar to the other, it can be possible that it is a larger value, and because of the Huygens principle (every spot a wave reaches acts as a new starting point), it can be reasoned to work like that.

Light intensity could be higher due to constructive interferences, as well as it could be lower due to destructive interferences, there is no reason to assume the first case over the second :D. But whatever, who would assume realism when the candle light propagates along a square shape ;) ?

I do not, but its better to make sure nobody will. :)
But to have more realistic puzzles, I already got a Medium idea: same thing, with hexagons, and coordinates (or number of hexagon, in a large hexagonal room) for the location.
Do you think it will be better, and fit for the medium role?

Honestly no, no offense, but I think that would not make much difference and would be as straightforward as this one. IMO there are already way enough trivial problems in the Easy/Medium sections that are worthless as they do not teach anything to beginners.

Hey Niako, randomly went here and found your comment. I agree with you on your last point but then I was wondering two things : are there uncovered but worth Easy/Medium topics ? and is there a list of topics that should be taught to beginners ?

I think that there are lots of uncovered DP- or greedy-solvable topics for instance (I'm only talking about the medium section here) and that when such a topic is covered, it usually is solvable by brute-force due to weak inputs. It is hard to give a list of "worth" topics as there are lots of algorithms that are not actually "useful" for CG games/contests (while puzzles are in the "practice" section, hence supposedly there to practice for contests?...) But anyway, you can for instance check out these lists (not exhaustive, not perfect, not particularly representative of what might be missing):
http://rosalind.info/problems/tree-view/?location=algorithmic-heights
https://open.kattis.com/problem-sources/KTH%20CSC%20Popup%202005

People above a certain level get access to the list of all the approved puzzles. I do not know the exact level, but it is between 20 and 32.

All I did was to click on "Contribute", then choose "accepted", and find the first puzzle among the few one I had in mind.
Level 29

I agree, it should have been in the easy section. But otherwise a nice puzzle. As I'm getting accustomed with the python, the spaces between the elements do not disturb mutch. No matter whether to iterate over 'input().split()' or just over the 'input()'. Thought the diagrams with spaces are visually more appealing to look at :)

If I understand correctly, you can handle spaces in python so it is best to keep them.

How stupid do you think this sounds ?

Please don't be rude! To add the insult to injury, you did not even bother to read my entire comment. How stupid do you think it could make your remark? Yes python can handle both cases, but the meaning was, that from the technical point of view I do not care if the spaces are there or not, but it is aesthetically more pleasing to view the statement and the tests when the spaces are included.

Actually, I have already given a link to a puzzle where things (aesthetics included) are done the right way. So I have decided not to answer to the second part of your message.

I will only add that not only extra spaces introduce some issues (starting at the design of a relevant stub), they do not help much to distinguish between X and C.

One addition: The rule that the spot tuched by two candles also matters for one reason: It could be a summary of the two or more values, thus creating an even stronger point, and change everything. 
So because of that, it should stay, as a statement.
